climbs.name: Al Capone
climbs.fa: Equiped by Juan Henriquez, FFA: Kelly Thorpe

content.description:
Once you've arrived at the second to last draw of Scarface, shake out and prepare for battle. Head up and right through a small crux, then fun flowing climbing along the lip leads to the final crux. From here you are almost there, easy moves through the final small roof lead to the chain. Super cool route! Skipping the last 2 bolts on the send makes it easier to clip the chains above the roof. Originally graded M12 but probably M11/12-? 



Climbs scarface and continues on and right through the massive lip and up to the chains, many bolts (fixed draws)

bolts (fixed draws)

An easy starts leads to burly moves as the wall steepens to near horizontal at the top. Step left at the last draw to the anchor.

The first route on your left in the cave
Fixed draws

Big moves on big holds! Start just past Scarface, and head up the wall to a slot at the base of the roof. Reach a full wingspan straight up, cut your feet, and launch into 15+ meters of roof climbing. 



Just past Scarface.

17 Fixed draws, Anchor equipped to lower off

Start on the face below a chossy ledge. 3 bolts of technical climbing gain the ledge. Rest here before blasting up and right, pull the crux bulge on the right side and finish with a very technical face and mantel to chains.



On the left edge of the Cave, 10 meters left of Scarface.

Bolts

Start below the overhang and work your way up and slightly right, from here blast up and left through the crux overhang (bouldery) and onto the fun but technical slab above.



The furthest route on the left, about 12 meters left of Solitary Confinement

bolts, fixed anchor

An easy start up the corner leads to hard moves on small feet through the horizontal roof, after a few less steep moves the route finishes with more horizontal climbing to the anchor. Much burlier than its neighbor

The second route you pass in the cave. Look for the obvious corner
Fixed draws

From the left side of the cave. Follow the bolts up some looser rock for several meters then several pulls on good but hidden holds take you through the steep and solid headwall. Pull over the top of the headwall and follow the slab to the anchor

Just to the left of the main cave 
Bolts with fixed draws

A large sunny drytooling crag on Grotto Mountain, Canmore. All the routes here are great hard rigs that make for a great workout on the arms. A great place to come on cold days due to the sun exposure.
